text: The Fallout series takes place decades
after nuclear war riddles the world

with radiation, and the only human
survivors are the people who moved
into giant underground vaults.

Plot elements and ulterior motives
aside, could human society really

survive decades or centuries in fallout
shelters like the Vault-Tec Vaults?

Let’s pick up a Science
Bobblehead and find out.
(SPLASH INTRO)

There are a few different
kinds of radiation.
In the Fallout scenario, we’re concerned

with ionizing radiation from the
nuclear fallout, which is the

stream of alpha particles, beta
particles, or gamma rays
shooting out from unstable atoms.

Time, distance, and shielding
are the three main factors that

affect your chances of surviving
ionizing radiation.

You want to be exposed for as short a
time as possible, be as far away as
you can, and have the most shielding.
What does that sound like?
A fallout shelter.

The Vault Dweller Survival Guide,
or VDSG for short,

provides some stats on Vault 13,
which was underground, covered
by 200 feet of earth and a 12 ft.
thick steel door.
But what if you live somewhere you can’t dig?
Here’s chemist Raychelle Burke.

“Since digging 200 feet underground
isn’t going to work everywhere,

what can we do to protect
ourselves from the fallout?

NASA has developed some radiation
shielding for space flight, which
could be adapted for fallout shelters.

Scientists are developing nanomaterials
that can resist radiation,
high heat and high pressure.

Walls of carbon nanotubes
are promising candidates.

Current research suggests that carbon
nanotubes provide protection from

radiation, and (ounce for ounce) are at
least 100 times stronger than steel.”

For electronics, which could fry
easily under radiation, there is
another nanotech called resistive

memory, which is made of
an electrode/electrolyte
sandwich that looks promising.
Will it protect us and our gadgets

against Raiders? Well.... that's
still in the testing phase.

But long-term life in the vault
requires more than just thick walls.
We need power, water & food.

“Vaults have limited storage so fossil
fuels wouldn’t last you very long.

Solar power is out if you’re 200
feet underground and don’t want
Deathclaws rippin’ up your solar panels.

Shoo! Different vaults have
different power sources.

Vault 8 runs on nuclear power, and
Vault 13 uses geothermal energy,

which uses the heat of the earth to turn
water into steam to power generators.

Fuel cells could also work -- they can
produce electricity, heat, and water.

And unlike batteries, fuel cells
don’t need to be recharged, as

long as they get a constant
supply of fuel, like hydrogen.”

While in Fallout and Fallout 2
there are cool “water chips” to
purify water, we don’t have those.

After a nuclear war, irradiated
water would be a real problem,
with many sources being contaminated.
One possible purification method uses

graphene oxide to remove radioactive
elements from the water.
“And how about food?
In the VDSG, Vault 13 comes equipped
with “hydro-agricultural farms” to provide food.

Today, we have aquaponics, or
cultivating crops and fish in a
closed water system - no soil needed.

Like in soil-based farming, the
nutrients living things need to
survive are cycled through the system.

Fish excretes Nitrogen, but too
much nitrogen can produce
ammonia that’s deadly to.

Good news is, plants need
nitrogen in order to survive.

Put the two together and the fish
provide the nitrogen for plants
while the plants filter the water for
the fish - a small-scale nitrogen cycle.
Commercial aquaponics operations have

raised tomatoes, herbs,
tilapia, catfish and more.
SO much better than InstaMash.
Trust me.”
So now we have a shelter, power, water and food.
Makes for a cozy Vault, doesn’t it?

Now if they can just take care
of that radroach problem…
What would you bring to your vault?
